And their debut with High Voltage was just awesome. Here are my breakdowns of each song:<BR>1. It's a Long Way to the Top (If You Wanna Rock and Roll): and AC/DC classic, and one of my favourite songs by them. The guitar riff is a little repetitive, but by no means detracts from the song. The bagpipes are a spectacular addition to this song.<BR>2. Rock and Roll Singer: a very similar song to It's a Long Way to the Top, but forgivable as this is one of Bon's finer moments as far as lyrics go.<BR>3.The Jack: an in-concert favourite. I don't particularly care for this song, but the ingenious double entendres are always entertaining to listen to.<BR>4. Live Wire: my favourite AC/DC song. From the pounding, regimented bass line at the opening, to Angus' wonderful guitar work, to Bon's fine lyrics, this is a joy to listen to and never gets tiring for me. By far the highlight of the album.<BR>5. TNT: another AC/DC masterpiece and deservedly so. The guitar riff is very catchy, and soon you'll be pounding your head up and down with the beat and screaming &quot;OI!OI!OI!&quot; with the band.<BR>6. Can I Sit Next To You Girl: This song and Little Lover are the two songs on this disc that could be considered &quot;filler&quot; but are by no means exercises in tedium to listen to.<BR>7. Little Lover: similar to the Jack. Gets down to AC/DC's blues roots. As I stated earlier, this is nothing but filler.<BR>8. She's Got Balls: I love the intro to this song, and the rest of the song follows along quite nicely. Not up there with the best of this album, but those are very lofty standards and thus this is still a very good song.<BR>9. High Voltage: a lot of people love this song, although I'm not one of them. It's a good song for sure, but pales in comparison to Live Wire, TNT and It's a Long Way to the Top. Nonetheless, you'll still be singing &quot;High Voltage rock n' roll!&quot;<BR>If this review made it seem like this album is not one of the finest pieces of rock ever assembled, my apologies, because it is! Live Wire is, in my opinion, worth the purchase price alone and TNT doesn't hurt its cause either. This is truly and essential part of your AC/DC collection.

0790729350|4.0|A previous reviewer has made mention of the fact that so much of the best music from the concert doesn't appear in the documentary footage.  I concur, and I advise anyone who owns the motion picture to buy the soundtrack as well.  There were tremendous performances by Sly and the Family Stone, Paul Butterfield, Melanie, Mountain, Johnny Winter, Creedence Clearwater Revival and others that ended up on the cutting room floor.  Time couldn't possibly allow all three days' worth of music, but the film was about so much more than the musical performances.  <br />Aside from the atrocious weather that plagued the event, some of the performances were awful, including the Who's set, which sounded like they were playing in a cardboard box; Arlo Guthrie's, who stormed off in anger after constant helicopter interruptions; CSNY's, with their out-of-tune guitars and off-key vocals; and the Grateful Dead's (absent from both the film and the soundtrack), which ended when a rain-soaked Jerry Garcia was electrocuted by a mike-stand.  Ironically, the thrilling conclusion to the festival, given by the Jimi Hendrix Experience, was witnessed by only a few thousand stragglers, as many people had already gone home -- or never even made it to the show because of all the abandoned cars on the highways.<br />Some very poignant and very human moments were included in the film, especially those with the chief of police and the Port-o-San cleaner, as well as some difficult moments, such as the irate farmer who lost his milk supply and had his fences broken due to the massive crowds and blocked highways(\\"It's a sh*tty mess!\\" he says).  Joan Baez' protest-laden set was equally poignant, and Country Joe MacDonald's exhortation \\"How do you expect to stop a war if you don't sing?!?\\" epitomizes the attitude of the Nation's youth towards an unpopular conflict and \\"the establishment.\\"<br />Most wonderful in all the film were the interviews with festival-goers and the impromptu stage announcements, interspersed between the concert footage and the stylistic, multi-screened editing.  How they managed to dub all those various performance clips with the soundtrack is amazing in itself.<br />This tremendous work of art won an Academy Award, and gives great snapshots of popular culture of the late 1960's.  It's an important piece of American film and also of American history.  But once again, if you really want to experience the MUSIC, buy the film AND the soundtrack.

The LP opens with the [hard]-slap attack of \\"Cochise\\" and never lets up from there. These 4 men simply belong together and create some of the heaviest, catchiest and dopest hard rock I've heard in quite a while. Chris Cornell has lost of his banshee wailing power from his Soundgarden days and while this LP lacks the artsy pretensions of say, \\"Superunknown\\" or Cornell's own \\"Euphoria Morning\\", the lyrics are some of his best and the guitar playing here will have you slapping your dashboard in utter disbelief!<br />Everything here is worth repeated listening and will most likely still sound fresh 15 or 20 years from now.<br />A great debut and here's hoping that this isn't a one shot project for these guys.

B00006LSCX|5.0|The original CD released a year ago was already a piece of pop masterpiece in recent years. A great dance pop album that leaves you prancing and dancing all night long.<br /><br />Everything from straight pop to electronic to high energy dance. Look out for the re-issue which includes a second bonus CD of mostly remixes. Although this is admittedly a last ditch attempt to milk more money from the Fever mania, it is by no means subpar. The reason being that the six remixes are some of the best Kylie has to offer and from the past year. There's the clever amalgamation of Blue Monday and Can't Get You Out of My Head, the club favorites from Roger Sanchez's Release The S-Man Dub of In Your Eyes, Scrumfrog's dub of Love At Fiirst Sight and the phenomenal Fischerspooner mix of Come Into My World. Flowing seamlessly from one mix to another, the bons CD ends with the Scooby Doo soundtrack song Whenever You Feel Like It.<br /><br />Though you might have the original Cd, you just have to get the re-issue! Clever marketing but ultimately worth your every cent!
